title: Brussels Sprouts Baaji (indian Spiced Brussels Sprouts)
summary: The recipe Brussels Sprouts Baaji (indian Spiced Brussels Sprouts) is ready in roughly 20 minutes and is definitely a spectacular gluten free, dairy free, and whole 30 option for lovers of Indian food. For $1.33 per serving, this recipe covers 20% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe serves 2. One serving contains 211 calories, 5g of protein, and 16g of fat. It works well as a side dish. Not a lot of people made this recipe, and 1 would say it hit the spot. Head to the store and pick up chile peppers, brussels sprouts, spice grinder, and a few other things to make it today. With a spoonacular score of 67%, this dish is solid. Try Spiced Lemony Brussels Sprouts, Roasted Brussels Sprouts With Spiced Candied Kumquats, and Kittencal's Roasted Brussels/Brussels Sprouts for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Indian can be paired with Gruener Veltliner, Riesling, and Sparkling ros√©. The best wine for Indian food will depending on the dish, of course, but these picks can be served chilled and have some sweetness to complement the spiciness and complex flavors of a wide variety of traditional dishes. The Berger Gruner Veltliner (1 Liter) with a 4.7 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 15 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Berger Gruner Veltliner (1 Liter)
productMatches.description: Berger's Gruner Veltliner is the quintessential Summer sipper! This Austrian white grape variety produces a crisp and mineral-focused wine with hints of citrus, lemon peel, lychee, and a touch of spiciness that may remind you of white pepper. Its refreshingly crisp body works great on a warm Summer day, especially when you're outdoors.
